STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 24, 2022
Aprille Sutton
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 Veterans Drive
Traverse City, MI 49684
RE: License #: CB280201037
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 Veterans Drive
Traverse City, MI 49684
Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 3/14-
3/18/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB280201037
Licensee Name: Child & Family Services of NW Michigan Inc
Licensee Address: 3785 Veterans Drive
Traverse City, MI 49684
Licensee Telephone #: (231) 946-8975
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Aprille Sutton, Administrator
Name of Facility: Child & Family Services of Northwestern
Michigan
Facility Address: 3785 Veterans Drive
Traverse City, MI 49684
Facility Telephone #: (231) 946-8975
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1990
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): March 14-18, 2022

Reviewed

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall
recommend to the department the issuance of a regular
license or the continuation of an active license only when
all rules are in compliance or both of the following
conditions exist:
(a) All non-compliances relating to the recommendation
are correctable.
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed.
1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation within a home
evaluation indicating that the home was not in compliance with all licensing rules;
however, the home was determined to be in full compliance and no CAP was
developed.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional
time is required, then the agency shall inform the foster
parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension and the
expected length of the extension. The total time for the
completion of the investigation shall not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained a special evaluation report that was
not completed within 45 days; however, a 45-day extension letter was not present
within the file.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
4

1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained a special evaluation report
indicating that the report was not written within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained a special evaluation that did not
include documentation that the report was provided to the youth's foster care worker.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age and
older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed
not more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least
every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that periodic
dental examinations were completed as required per MDHHS policy.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(a-h)
3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required information was provided to caregivers within the required timeframe.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
5

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
2 of 11 total open case files reviewed (8 foster care & 3 IL) contained 1 service plan
not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
Interim Inspection Report dated 4/21/20, CAP approved 6/9/20
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at
least once every month.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed were missing documented foster home
visits for one month.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
6

Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days
of the FTM.
8 of 11 open case files reviewed (8 FC, 3 IL) did not contain documentation that all
required FTM's and/or all required FTM paperwork was completed as required. The
majority of missing FTM's were related to service plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
Interim Inspection Report dated 4/21/20, CAP approved 6/9/20
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must
review the case service plan and all linked assessments
and treatment plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case
service plan review may occur during monthly case
consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
2 of 11 open case files reviewed contained 1 report that was approved outside of 14
days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED – previously cited as 722-09
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
7

 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review,
and I will have the opportunity to express my
disagreement with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan when the information is
presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign
the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and
document actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
8 of 11 open case files reviewed (8FC, 3 IL) were either missing or had late required
signatures on PATPs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED -previously cited as ISEP 6.33
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
Interim Inspection Report dated 4/21/20, CAP approved 6/9/20
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
8

COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
3 of 14 open/closed case files reviewed did not contain action summaries completed
as required.
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
9

and obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
5 of 11 open case files reviewed (8FC, 3IL) did not contain documentation that
medical passports were updated/generated/provided/signed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED -previously cited as MISEP 6.49
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/9/21, CAP approved 4/5/21
Interim Inspection Report dated 4/21/20, CAP approved 6/9/20
PA 116 Confidentiality
722.120(3)
A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested, the
facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall
be properly safeguarded by the childcare organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of the
information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:
1 of 8 open foster home case files reviewed identified the involvement of CPS in the
complaint/investigation.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Location of Medical Passport signature pages in MiSACWIS.
 A 3706 cannot be completed/signed prior to a completed renewal assessment.
 Signatures on 3080s must be uploaded.
 Review licensing reports for accuracy.
 Quality visit standards must be documented for each home visit.
 TDM paperwork does not replace FTM paperwork per current policy.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
10

 When accepting a case transfer from another agency assure that all required
documentation is present.
 The renewal letters sent to families refer to enclosed “necessary forms.” It is
advised that the letter identify the forms specifically.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
This CAP was submitted in response to the 2021 licensing renewal inspection and
was approved on 4/5/2021. The agency is in compliance with multiple areas of that
CAP; however, as noted within this report, there are areas in which the agency has
not demonstrated effective implementation of the CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
I reviewed and discussed the Chief Administrator assessment which identified areas
of concern related to staff turnover and challenges related to accepting cases from
other agencies.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported being supported and encouraged by the
knowledgeable and available superiors. No concerns were reported.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
11

March 23, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 24, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
